Patrick Cutrone: “I consider myself as a normal person, and I don’t think I’m any different from other people. I’m maybe a little luckier than the other people, because I can do what I love as a profession."

’ve been at Milan for 13 years and I was really struggling for the first few seasons, and this was due to the fact that I finished late at school, then I had to eat, and then straight to training, which was very tiring.

“My desire has never failed me, and my father has always been by my side, and I have always listened to him. On the pitch, I am a bit tense, and I have my superstitious rituals before I enter the training, or perhaps San Siro or away matches.”

Milan’s lawyer assures they’re “optimistic” ahead of next week’s UEFA verdict on Financial Fair Play.

The Rossoneri have been rejected for both a voluntary and a settlement agreement, and will be sanctioned for violating FFP.

Punishments could include a fine or squad limitation, but they could also be thrown out of next season’s Europa League.

“We’re optimistic by nature,” Roberto Cappelli, the club’s lawyer, told ANSA.

“We have good arguments and we hope to assert them.

Turkish offers for Kalinic

Milan striker Nikola Kalinic is considered hot property in Turkey, with interest from Galatasaray, Fenerbahce and Besiktas.

According to La Gazzetta dello Sport, the Croatia international is likely to end up in the Turkish Super Lig.

The 30-year-old was a big investment from Fiorentina last summer, costing €25m, but contributed only six goals and six assists in 41 competitive games.

While China was an option, it now seems as if Turkey is the next destination, with Galatasaray, Fenerbahce and Besiktas all ready to swoop.

The problem, claims the report, is that they all want Kalinic on loan with option to buy.

Sevilla remain contenders and the forward would prefer a Spanish switch.

Lazio join Gelson Martins race

Lazio and Milan are in the running for Portugal international Gelson Martins, one of several Sporting CP players to terminate his contract.

The 23-year-old right-sided winger spent his entire career at Sporting, but is leaving as a free agent along with many of his teammates.

They were attacked by masked thugs in the training ground and sued the club to rescind the contracts, claiming the President actively encouraged the aggression.

Milan, Benfica, Arsenal and other Premier League sides have already shown interest, but Lazio are joining in.

According to Il Messaggero newspaper, the Aquile could have the upper hand thanks to their good rapport with agent Jorge Mendes.

Gelson Martins contributed 13 goals and 13 assists in 52 competitive games this season.

小組出局

Milan could try to get Brazilian Ganso on loan with option to buy from Sevilla as part of a possible exchange for Nikola Kalinic.

According to Calciomercato.it, the 28-year-old trequartista is on Coach Gennaro Gattuso’s wish-list.

Ganso had been linked with the Rossoneri many times over the years, but never made it to Serie A, instead leaving Sao Paulo for Sevilla in 2016.

He managed four goals and three assists this season, but only made 11 competitive appearances.

It’s reported Milan could try to take Ganso on loan with option to buy, perhaps even as part of Sevilla’s bid for Croatia international Kalinic.

Reina calls Callejon to Milan

Pepe Reina left Napoli as a free agent for Milan and is reportedly now trying to convince Jose Callejon to join him.

The veteran goalkeeper’s contract was not renewed at the Stadio San Paolo and he decided to put pen to paper with the Rossoneri.

According to the Corriere dello Sport newspaper, Reina is actively urging his fellow Spaniard Callejon to become part of the Milan project too.

There have been repeated rumours over the last few months that Gennaro Gattuso and the San Siro giants were interested in signing Callejon.

With Maurizio Sarri’s exit and the arrival of Carlo Ancelotti, a change of tactics is to be expected.

Callejon is 31 years old and under contract with Napoli until June 2020.

This season, he scored 12 goals with 17 assists in 50 competitive games for Napoli.

Croatia have officially sent Milan striker Nikola Kalinic home with Coach Zlatko Dalic stating “I need ready and healthy players”.

It emerged this morning that the forward had refused to come on for Mario Mandzukic in the win over Nigeria, as he claimed he had a back injury.

"In agreement with his coaching staff, Croatia head coach Zlatko Dalić decided to exclude Nikola Kalinić from the World Cup squad. Kalinić leaves Croatia basecamp in Roshchino on Monday and returns to Croatia," a statement from the Croatian Federation reads.

The Coach also commented on the decision, which was made in response to the Nigeria game.

“During the Nigeria match, Kalinic was warming-up and should have come in the second half,” Dalic confirmed.

“However, he said he wasn’t ready to go on because he felt a back problem. He did the same thing against Brazil and England, saying he wasn’t ready, and for yesterday’s training session too.

“I accepted it calmly, because I need ready and healthy players who can help their teammates. He’s not like that, on three occasions he hasn't been ready, so I made this decision.”

Milan to discover European fate

Milan will meet UEFA on Tuesday as they prepare to discover whether they will play Europa League football next season.

The meeting will take place at UEFA’s headquarters in the Swiss town of Nyon, with a verdict on Milan’s European fate expected ‘within 48-72 hours’.

Representing the Rossoneri are CEO Marco Fassone, financial officer Valentina Montanari, communications officer Fabio Guadagnini, economist Umberto Lago – also one of Financial Fair Play’s (FFP) founding fathers, who assisted the club with their settlement agreement – and two lawyers.

The sextet will plead the Diavolo’s before UEFA’s Adjudicatory Chamber, which rejected their agreement on May 22.

In the event Milan are banned from participating in the Europa League, Sport Mediaset claims they will appeal the decision to the Court of Arbitration of Sport (CAS) ‘within 7-10 days’ of the governing body’s verdict.

Their argument would focus on the ‘commitment’ of Elliott Management – the hedge fund which helped fund Li Yonghong’s takeover last year with a €303m loan – and ‘transparency of the club’s accounts’.

Badelj: Kalinic had an ego

Milan Badelj believes Croatia made the right decision to send Nikola Kalinic home from the World Cup. “You have to put your ego to one side…”

Kalinic was ejected from Croatia’s World Cup campaign after he refused to come on as a substitute during their 2-0 win against Nigeria on Saturday, and Badelj praised his country for dealing with the issue swiftly.

“What happened didn’t affect us,” the departing Fiorentina midfielder told reporters.

“The first thing is the team, you have to put your ego to one side when you talk about your national team.

“The same respect is needed at club level, but it’s needed even more at international level because it’s a more specific situation and we’re not here as much.

“The important thing that we maintain unity and a good atmosphere in the dressing room.”

Fassone, Han Li and Milan Chief Commercial Officer Lorenzo Giorgetti were in England to meet the new Milan member who wants to know the commercial revenues of the club. The parties interested in entering Milan are two American investors [Corriere della Sera]

The latest update is the new Milan shareholder could acquire the majority of the club immediately. The analysis of Milan's accounts have started some time ago and are in its final stage [CorSera]

Each of Merrill Lynch and Goldman Sachs brought two similar dossiers after long and secret negotiations with two separate American funds with recognizable frontmen that intend to acquire the majority of Milan within 2-3 years [@PietroMazzarra]

This will then give Yonghong Li the time to return the investment made. Goldman Sachs presented a €550M offer for 75-77% of the shares and a 3-year climb. Merrill Lynch's offer still confidential but according to rumors the figures are close in terms of equity and economically
